page.title: 04BETHERSDEN RELIGION (1)
page.content: ST MARGARET'S CHURCH IS MENTIONED IN THE DOMESDAY MONACHORUM, A DOCUMENT WRITTEN SOON AFTER 1100, WHICH STATES THAT THE CHURCH WAS ACCUSTOMED TO PAY 28d TO THE ARCHBISHOP AT EASTER. THE PRESENT BUILDING BUILT MAINLY OF LOCAL RAGSTONE CONTAINS SOME FINE SLABS OF BETHERSDEN MARBLE ONCE QUARRIED IN THE AREA. AMONGST THE MEMORIALS ARE TWO BRASSES TO THE LOVELACE FAMILY. THE TOWER CONTAINS A PEAL OF SIX BELLS THE FOURTH OF WHICH IS THOUGHT TO HAVE BEEN CAST IN A LONDON FOUNDRY BETWEEN 1328 AND 1348. THE BAPTIST CHAPEL OF RED BRICK,TILE HANGING AND SLATE,WAS BUILT IN 1804 AND SUBSEQUENTLY EXTENDED.CLOSE TO THE CHAPEL IS A RECENTLY BUILT MANSE. THE METHODIST CHAPEL OF RED BRICK AND SLATE WAS BUILT ON FORGE HILL IN 1875. THIS REPLACED A SMALLER BUILDING WHICH IS STILL STANDING IMMEDIATELY OPPOSITE
